But wow, that flight is something I will not forget. Amazing to see all the hard work coming together, and seeing her fly. That flight profile is something totally new when it comes to rockets, and it worked flawlessly. And when you consider just how big that thing is, that is just amazing. Such a shame she lost pressure at the end, I wonder if the sudden transition back to vertical was just a bit too quick for the fuel to settle back in the bottom of the header tanks? If so, maybe a slightly slower transition - using the flaps to start with would help in future? But I am sure the folks at SpaceX gathered a ton of data about the flight, and can work out from that the cause of the low fuel pressure. But all in all, everyone involved with the design and building of these prototypes should be feeling very proud of this achievement. I noticed right at the start of the belly flop maneuver that it configured its fore and aft draglets opposite to what I expected it to do.  I would have thought they would fold the front ones and extend the aft ones to get it to rotate, but instead they used the RCS to induce rotation.  I wonder if they were afraid of over rotating and loss of control?  Falling backwards like that, the way they did it makes it more stable, for sure, but I'll be looking out what (hopefully) SN9 does, see if they try using the draglets more with lessons learnt from this flight.
